abstract: <jats:p>In this study, the biodiversity of Chironomidae was investigated in Palmer Park Pond A, an urban vernal pond in Detroit, Michigan, USA. This study is developed as part of our ongoing Public Environmental Outreach Program at the Detroit Exploration and Nature Center in Palmer Park. Twenty-one Chironomidae species were discovered in and on the adjacent riparian vegetation of this pond using molecular and morphological methods. Three species <jats:italic>Bryophaenocladius palmerparcum</jats:italic> Namayandeh & Hudson <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>Limnophyes stagnum</jats:italic> Namayandeh, Guerra & Ram <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, and <jats:italic>Rheocricotopus</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>s. s.</jats:italic>) <jats:italic>angustus</jats:italic> Namayandeh & Hudson <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> are new to science. <jats:italic>Bryophaenocladius palmerparcum</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> and <jats:italic>L. stagnum</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> are unusual Orthoclads, with <jats:italic>B. palmerparcum</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> possessing a setose, short, and wide anal point and <jats:italic>L. stagnum</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> lacking lanceolate setae on both sexes. Based on the shape of superior volsella, <jats:italic>R. angustus</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, belongs to the <jats:italic>effusus</jats:italic> group, which was also confirmed by DNA barcoding molecular analysis. In this study, a new faunistic record was also found for the Nearctic as well as four new faunistic records for the state of Michigan. Ephemeral aquatic habitats such as vernal pools are often overlooked or destroyed by urbanization activities, controlling vector species, creating groomed fields, and/or residential development. Therefore, finding these new species demonstrates the biodiversity value of vernal ponds as important habitats, further motivating us to preserve them.</jats:p>
title: New species and a fascinating diversity of Chironomidae (Diptera, Insecta) in and around an overlooked urban vernal pool
